abstract.text: We present the first search for the rare decay of η ′ into K ± π ∓ in J/ψ → φη ′ , using a sample of 1.3 × 10 9 J/ψ events collected with the BESIII detector.
No significant signal is observed, and the upper limit at the 90% confidence level for the ratio B(η ′ →K ± π ∓ ) B(η ′ →γπ + π − ) is determined to be 1.3 × 10 −4 .
In addition, we report the measurement of the branching fraction of J/ψ → φη ′ to be (5.10 ± 0.03(stat.) ± 0.32(syst.)) × 10 −4 , which agrees with previous results from BESII.

body_text.text: Non-leptonic weak decays are valuable tools for testing the Standard Model (SM), the Kobayashi-Maskawa (KM) mechanism, and the unitarity of the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix, and for exploring physics beyond the SM.

Among non-leptonic decays, the decay of the light pseudoscalar meson η ′ → K ± π ∓ is interesting because it is fundamental to understand the long-standing problem of the ∆I = 1/2 rule in weak nonleptonic interactions.
The experimental ∆I = 1/2 rule was first established in the decay K → ππ.
A neutral kaon may decay into a two-pion final state with isospin I = 0 or I = 2 with amplitude A 0 or A 2 , respectively.

As the real parts of the amplitudes, ReA 0 is dominated by ∆I = 1/2 transitions and ReA 2 receives contributions from ∆I = 3/2 transitions, the former transitions dominate ReA 0 , which expresses the so-called ∆I = 1/2 rule [1,2] ReA 0 ReA 2 = 22.35.
Despite nearly 50 years of efforts, the microscopic dynamical mechanism responsible for such a striking phenomenon is still elusive.
The decay η ′ → K ± π ∓ receives contributions from both the ∆I = 1/2 and ∆I = 3/2 parts of the weak hamiltonian [3].
It is possible to see whether the ∆I = 1/2 rule is functional in this type of decay, and this could shed light on the origin of this rule.

The branching fraction of η ′ → K ± π ∓ decay is predicted to be of the order of 10 −10 or higher [3], with a large long-range hadronic contribution expected, which should become observable in high luminosity electron-positron collisions.
At present, there is no experimental information on the decay η ′ → K ± π ∓ .
The world's largest sample of 1.3 × 10 9 J/ψ events produced at rest and collected with the BESIII detector therefore offers a good opportunity to search for this rare decay.
In this paper, the measurement of the ratio
is presented, where the η ′ is produced in the decay J/ψ → φη ′ .

The advantage of comparing these two η ′ decay channels is that parts of the systematic uncertainties due to the tracking, the particle identification (PID), the branching fractions B(J/ψ → φη ′ ) and B(φ → K + K − ), and the number of J/ψ events cancel in the ratio.
A measurement of the branching fraction J/ψ → φη ′ is also presented in which φ is reconstructed in its K + K − decay mode and η ′ is detected in the γπ + π − decay mode.
This can be compared with the results reported by the BESII [4], MarkIII [5], and DM2 [6] collaborations.
II.
DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION
BEPCII is a double-ring e + e − collider designed to provide a peak luminosity of 10 33 cm −2 s −1 at the center-ofmass (c.m.) energy of 3.770 GeV.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The BESIII [7] detector, with a geometrical acceptance of 93% of the 4π stereo angle, is operating in a magnetic field of 1.0 T provided by a superconducting solenoid magnet.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: It is composed of a helium-based drift chamber (MDC), a plastic scintillator Time-Of-Flight (TOF) system, a CsI(Tl) electromagnetic Calorimeter (EMC) and a multi-layer resistive plate chamber (RPC) muon counter system (MUC).
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Monte Carlo (MC) simulations are used to determine the mass resolutions and detection efficiencies.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The GEANT4-based simulation software BOOST [8] includes the geometric and material description of the BESIII detector, the detector response, and the digitization models, as well as the detector running conditions and performance.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The production of the J/ψ resonance is simulated with the MC event generator KKMC [9,10], while the decays are generated by EVTGEN [11] for known decay modes with branching fractions set to the Particle Data Group (PDG) [12] world average values, and by LUND-CHARM [13] for the remaining unknown decays.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The analysis is performed in the framework of the BESIII offline software system (BOSS) [14].
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: , candidate events are selected by requiring four well reconstructed charged tracks and at least one isolated photon in the EMC.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The four charged tracks are required to have zero net charge.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Each charged track, reconstructed using hits in the MDC, is required to be in the polar angle range | cos θ| < 0.93 and pass within ±10 cm of the interaction point along the beam direction, and within ±1 cm in the plane perpendicular to the beam, with respect to the interaction point.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: For each charged track, information from the TOF and the specific ionization measured in the MDC (dE/dx) are combined to form PID confidence levels (C.L.) for the K, π and p hypotheses, and the particle type with the highest C.L. is assigned to each track.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Two of the tracks are required to be identified as kaons and the remaining two tracks as pions.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Photon candidates are reconstructed by clusters of energy deposited in the EMC.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The energy deposited in the TOF counter in front of the EMC is included to improve the reconstruction efficiency and the energy resolution.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Photon candidates are required to have a deposited energy larger than 25 MeV in the barrel region (| cos θ| < 0.80) and 50 MeV in the end-cap region (0.86 < | cos θ| < 0.92).
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: EMC cluster timing requirements are used to suppress electronic noise and energy deposits that are unrelated to the event.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: To eliminate showers associated with charged particles, the angle between the cluster and the nearest track must be larger than 15 • .
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: A four-constraint (4C) kinematic fit is performed to the γK + K − π + π − hypothesis.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: For events with more than one photon candidate, the candidate combination with the smallest χ 2 4C is selected, and it is required that χ 2 4C < 50.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The scatter plot of M (γπ + π − ) versus M (K + K − ) is shown in Fig. 1, where the J/ψ → φη ′ decay is clearly visible.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: To extract the number of φη ′ events, an unbinned extended maximum likelihood fit is performed to the M (γπ + π − ) versus M (K + K − ) distribution with the requirements of 0.988 GeV/c 2 <
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Here, the signal shape for φ (i.e. F φ sig ) is modeled with a relativistic Breit-Wigner function convoluted with a Gaussian function taking into account the detector resolution; the signal shape for η ′ (i.e. F η ′ sig ) is described by a normal Breit-Wigner function convoluted with a Gaussian function.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The widths and masses of φ and η ′ are free parameters in the fit.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The background shape of φ (F non-φ bkg ) is described by a second order Chebychev polynomial function, and the background shape of η ′ (F non-η ′ bkg ) is described by a first order Chebychev polynomial function.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: All parameters related to the background shapes are free in the fit.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: N sig is the number of J/ψ → φη ′ , φ → K + K − , η ′ → γπ + π − signal events.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The backgrounds are divided into three categories: non-φη ′ background (i.e. J/ψ → γK
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: are the corresponding three background yields.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The resulting fitted number of signal events is N sig = (3132
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: (a) and
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: (b), respectively.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The detection efficiency, 32.96 ± 0.04%, is obtained from the MC simulation in which the angular distribution and the shape of M (π + π − ) are taken into account according to a previous BESIII measurement for η ′ → π + π − e + e − [15], where the non-resonant contribution (known as the "box anomaly") is included in the with projections of the fit result superimposed for J/ψ → φη ′ , φ → K + K − , η ′ → γπ + π − .
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The dots with errors are for data, the solid curve shows the result of the fit to signal plus background distributions, the long-dashed curve is for φη ′ signal, the dot-dashed curve shows the non-η ′ -peaking background, the dotted curve shows the non-φ-peaking background, and the short-dashed curve is for non-φη ′ background.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: To search for η ′ → K ± π ∓ , the two-body decay J/ψ → φη ′ is chosen because of its simple event topology, K + K − K ± π ∓ , and because the narrow φ meson is easy to detect through φ → K + K − decay.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The selection criteria for the charged tracks are the same as that for the J/ψ → φη ′ , η ′ → γπ + π − decay.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Three tracks are required to be identified as kaons with the combination of TOF and dE/dx information and the remaining one is required to be identified as a pion.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: A 4C kinematic fit imposing energy-momentum conservation is performed under the K + K − K ± π ∓ hypothesis, and a requirement of χ 2 4C < 50 is imposed.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: To suppress the dominant background contamination from J/ψ → φπ + π − , the χ 2 4C of the K + K − K ± π ∓ hypothesis is required to be less than that for the K + K − π + π − hypothesis.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Candidates for φ → K + K − are reconstructed from the K + K − combination with invariant mass closest to the nominal mass value.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The remaining kaon together with the pion form the η ′ candidate.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Fig. 3 (a) shows the scatter plot to the invariant mass M (K + K − ) versus M (K ± π ∓ ).
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: The process φη ′ (η ′ → K ± π ∓ ) would result in an enhancement of events around the nominal masses of the φ and η ′ mesons, while no evident cluster is seen.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Within three standard deviations of the φ mass, |M (K + K − ) − M (φ)| < 15 MeV/c 2 , the K ± π ∓ invariant mass distribution is displayed in Fig. 3  (b); a few events are retained around the η ′ mass region, shown as the dots with error bars.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: To estimate the number of signal events passing the selection criteria, a region of ±3σ around the η ′ nominal mass is selected, that is |M (K ± π ∓ ) − M (η ′ )| < 7 MeV/c 2 , where σ = 2.2 MeV is the mass resolution determined from MC simulation.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Only one event survives in the signal region for further analysis.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: To investigate the potential background contributions, a study with an inclusive MC sample of 1.2 × 10 9 generic J/ψ decays is performed.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: It is found that the remaining background events mainly come from J/ψ → φπ + π − .
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: Therefore an exclusive MC sample of 1.3 × 10 6 J/ψ → φπ + π − events is generated in accordance with the partial wave analysis results of Ref.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION
II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: This sample corresponds to twice the expected J/ψ → φπ + π − events in data.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: After normalizing to the world average value for B(J/ψ → φπ + π − ), 2.0 events are expected in the Kπ mass range of [0.88, 1.04] GeV/c 2 , with a total of 0.5 events in η ′ signal region, as shown by the solid histogram in Fig. 3 (b).
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: To conservatively estimate the upper limit, it is assumed that the only event in the signal region is a signal event.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: According to the Feldman-Cousins method [17], the corresponding upper limit of the number of events is N UL = 4.36 at the 90% C.L.
body_text.section: II. DETECTOR AND MONTE CARLO SIMULATION

body_text.text: IV.
SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

The systematic uncertainties in branching fraction measurement originate mainly from the differences of data and MC on tracking efficiency, photon reconstruction, PID efficiency, and the 4C kinematic fit, different fitting range and background shape, uncertainties from B(φ → K + K − ) and B(η ′ → γπ + π − ), total number of J/ψ events and MC statistics.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: Other uncertainties related to the common selection criteria of the channels J/ψ → φη ′ , η ′ → K ± π ∓ and J/ψ → φη ′ , η ′ → γπ + π − cancel to first order in the ratio between the branching fractions.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The systematic uncertainties associated with the tracking efficiency and PID efficiency have been studied in the analysis of J/ψ → ppπ + π − and J/ψ → K 0 S K ± π ∓ [18,19].
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The results indicate that the kaon/pion tracking and PID efficiencies for data agree with those of MC simulation within 1%.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The photon detection is estimated by the study of J/ψ → ρπ [18].
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The difference in the detection efficiency between data and MC is less than 1% per photon, which is taken as the systematic uncertainty because of the only photon in the J/ψ → φη ′ , η ′ → γπ + π − channel.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The uncertainty associated with the 4C kinematic fit comes from the difference between data and MC simulation.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The method used in this analysis is to correct the tracking parameters of the helix fit to reduce the difference between MC and data, as described in Ref.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES
IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: This procedure yields a systematic uncertainty of 0.3% and 1.0% for the measurement of B(J/ψ → φη ′ ) and the search of η ′ → K ± π ∓ , respectively.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: To estimate the systematic contribution due to the fit ranges, several alternative fits in different ranges are performed.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The maximum difference on the number of signal events from alternative fits in different mass ranges is 0.1%, and this value is taken as systematic uncertainty.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: To estimate the systematic contribution due to the background shape, a fit is performed replacing the 2nd-order Chebychev polynomial function with an Argus function [21]; the change of signal yields is found to be 0.04%, which is negligible.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The decay J/ψ → φη ′ , φ → K + K − , η ′ → γπ + π − is used as control sample to estimate the uncertainty from the φ mass window criterion in the search of η ′ → K ± π ∓ .
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The φ mass window criterion is applied to the control sample, and a fit is performed to M (γπ + π − ).
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: After considering the efficiency difference, the difference of 1.2% in the number of signal events between this fit and the nominal 2D fit is taken as the uncertainty from the φ mass window.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The uncertainties on the intermediate-decay branching fractions of φ → K + K − and η ′ → γπ + π − are taken from world average values [12].
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The above systematic uncertainties together with the uncertainties due to the number of J/ψ events [22,23] and MC statistics are all summarized in Table I, where the uncertainties associated with MDC tracking, PID, branching fraction of φ → K + K − cancel in the ratio
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The total systematic uncertainty is taken to be the sum in quadrature of the individual contributions.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.section: V. RESULTS

body_text.text: The obtained value for the branching fraction of J/ψ → φη ′ is (5.10 ± 0.03(stat.) ± 0.32(syst.)) × 10 −4 .
body_text.section: V. RESULTS

body_text.text: VI.
SUMMARY
Based on the 1.3 × 10 9 J/ψ events accumulated with the BESIII detector, a search for the non-leptonic weak decay η ′ → K ± π ∓ is performed for the first time through the J/ψ → φη ′ decay.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: No evidence for η ′ → K ± π ∓ is seen, and the 90% C.L. upper limit on the ratio of
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: B(η ′ →γπ + π − ) is measured to be 1.3 × 10 −4 .
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: Using the world average value of B(η ′ → γπ + π − ) [12], the corresponding upper limit on B(η ′ → K ± π ∓ ) is calculated to be 3.8 × 10 −5 .
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: For the determination of the ratio of B(η ′ →K ± π ∓ ) B(η ′ →γπ + π − ) , the J/ψ → φη ′ decay with φ → K + K − , η ′ → γπ + π − is analyzed and the corresponding branching fraction is B(J/ψ → φη ′ ) = (5.10 ± 0.03(stat.) ± 0.32(syst.)) × 10 −4 .
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: It is the most precise measurement to date and in agreement with the world average value.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY
